questions.question: The speaker's attitude toward the girl is --
The imagery of the breath in lines 6-7 and the breathing in line 20 stresses --
The speaker puts the orange on the counter because --

choices.answer: he knows it will look tempting.
he does not have another nickel.
he knows the saleslady is fond of oranges.
he wants the girl to see how generous he is.

questions.question: The imagery of the orange in lines 51-55

choices.answer: evokes his growing feeling of love
symbolizes the brightness of the boy's mood
is ironic because a twelve-year-old wouldn't like fruit
emphasizes the dreariness of the weather

questions.question: What is the purpose of the break between stanzas?

choices.answer: It develops the girl's demanding and selfish nature.
It suggests the saleslady's misunderstanding of his request.
It reveals a shift in the boy and girls' relationship.
It emphasizes the boldness of the purchase of chocolate.

questions.question: From whose point of view is the poem told?

choices.answer: a saleslady at the drug store

questions.question: Based on the last stanza, the reader can conclude that--

choices.answer: the boy will not eat the orange.
the girl will not speak to the boy again.
the boy will be arrested for shoplifting.
the boy and girl like each other.

questions.question: What is the definition of burned as it is used in line 10?

choices.answer: to injure or damage by exposure to fire, heat, or radiation

questions.question: What is the girl's attitude in lines 28-30 of the poem?
What is the author's purpose for using the simile in lines 42-45?

choices.answer: It foreshadows the immaturity of the relationship.
